snippet.textDisplay:
Look at what they did to ma boi, Dead Space.
THATS RIGHT IM STILL FUCKING PISSED OFF ABOUT THAT. I enjoyed every second of all three of the games, for different reasons (DS1 was terrifying. By DS2 i had acclimated to the atmosphere and tension, but the smoother mechanics and story kept me enthralled. DS3 was played entirely in Co-Op, and was thoroughly enjoyed, even without the atmosphere and horror coming into play as much. The DLC, tailored towards co-op, brought that tension back full swing however, as players were seeing different things, sometimes going mental on the other players screen, and all around co-op tailored shenanigans making a glorious time).

Idiots with ridiculous expectations ruined that series. And the ironic thing is that ever since, they've been hated by the majority of the DS fanbase for their fucking stupid decision and the demand for a DS4 has always been there. They would make bank if they made a DS4, but that would show shareholders just how little they know about their own market, so we'll not be getting that anytime soon. Fycking stupid people asking stupid reckons make me stupidly mad.

Bring back Dead Space you bunch of puckered holes.

snippet.textDisplay:
3:33 Or you know, people want to play some of the best games of yesteryear with graphics that didn't age like milk.

I'd put a "yet" there but we're pretty much at the pinnacle of how good video game graphics can get at this point. I mean, aside maybe from adding more flashy effects that is (can we really do better than 4k resolution for games? Probably not!). Frankly I feel sorry for NVIDIA right now. They made their entire brand around their graphics cards even though that's not even all they make. Meanwhile AMD will do just fine without new graphics cards.

snippet.textDisplay:
My take on this is similar, but actually less cynical for a change. Capcom and Square Enix have finally figured out what I've been saying for years.


You don't need to chase the hottest trends, and fight over a vanishingly small share of the same pie everyone else is eyeing, when you are already one of the undisputed greats in your own field. It's like Michael Jordan giving up on being the greatest NBA player alive, to be a low tier baseball pro. When you are the king of survival horror, or JRPGs, or whatever, it's absolute folly to abandon that hard won territory, to go off and rush out another PUBG clone, with a gatcha machine taped to it.


You don't need some new billion dollar idea that'll make your investors drop their panties, you just need craftsmanship and polish. Too often, the likes of EA, Activision and Bethesda try to cut those two corners, even though they are the cornerstones that their reputations need to rest on. It's no surprise that their directionless, crunch-reliant culture has eroded the foundations of public trust in their brands.


Do what you're good at, and pour yourself into it, and gamers will recognize game. If you need to return to your roots to remember who you are, go for it.
snippet.textOriginal:

It's like Michael Jordan giving up on being the greatest NBA player alive, to be a low tier baseball pro. When you are the king of survival horror, or JRPGs, or whatever, it's absolute folly to abandon that hard won territory, to go off and rush out another PUBG clone, with a gatcha machine taped to it.


You don't need some new billion dollar idea that'll make your investors drop their panties, you just need craftsmanship and polish. Too often, the likes of EA, Activision and Bethesda try to cut those two corners, even though they are the cornerstones that their reputations need to rest on. It's no surprise that their directionless, crunch-reliant culture has eroded the foundations of public trust in their brands.


Do what you're good at, and pour yourself into it, and gamers will recognize game. If you need to return to your roots to remember who you are, go for it.

snippet.textDisplay: Not sure I can really get on board with Jim's point here. I like some new games that have come out, there are good franchises being made that are getting people excited. The reason why people are excited for things based on old shit is because there's a lot of old shit out there with fanbases built up over a decade plus of sequels and stuff until those things become out of date with new technology letting developers polish old ideas into something better than what they could do in the 90s. People aren't just like "New things suck, we want old stuff", reputations and brand awareness grow over time. Sekiro is never going to be as well known as something like Devil May Cry 1 because there's been years and years for people to learn what DMC1 is.
snippet.textOriginal: Not sure I can really get on board with Jim's point here. I like some new games that have come out, there are good franchises being made that are getting people excited. snippet.textDisplay:
"Twenty years ago, Half-Life was a focal point in gaming's ongoing development as an artistic narrative medium; the next few years saw a slew of titles that combined AAA game design with genuine emotional story. But what happened between then and now?! Why are the games routinely rewarded with AAA status and income exclusively loot box-infested live service bullshit, games designed not to inspire or stimulate our emotions, but to numb them and hypnotize us into lab rats, mindlessly pawing the button that makes treats come out, while the games created with love and artistic integrity drown beneath waves of bottom-feeders like Hunt Down The Freeman, that tear chunks of rotten flesh from the corpses of Valve's children as Valve itself, once-habitual founders of new ages of narrative gaming, merely waves them on, barely glancing up from their tax paperwork?! What happened to you?! What happened to us?! To the people we were supposed to become?! ...I don't know, but it's probably safe to blame John Romero."
- Yahtzee, Hunt Down the Freeman

"(Sigh) You know why I still do these rundowns every year; it's because gamers as consumers have conceded too much fucking ground, and what counts as acceptable standard business practice inches more and more toward Fort Bullshit, Tennessee, every year. Twenty years ago, the relationship was, "Play one-third of our game for free as much as you like, and then consider paying this unworthy mortal twenty insignificant dollars for the rest, Your Grace." And somehow, that's turned into, "Pay in full now, stinking plebs, 'cos we showed you a logo. You can't have it for six months, and then you have to pay another ten bucks for the special helmet with a bell-end on the front so everyone knows what a cockhead you are." The pushback against loot boxes was a good start, but how about this? Let's all stop preordering stuff! Just for a year, six months maybe, trial period. If you're tempted, ask yourself: "Can I envision a scenario in which my decision to purchase this game might ultimately hinge on whether or not I can play it while wearing a special preorder cock helmet?" At least consider it, so the next year, I'm not saying, "Hey guys, how about we all stop ticking the box that says, 'Sony have the exclusive ownership rights to our blood'?" "
- Yahtzee, e3 2018
snippet.textOriginal:

Why are the games routinely rewarded with AAA status and income exclusively loot box-infested live service bullshit, games designed not to inspire or stimulate our emotions, but to numb them and hypnotize us into lab rats, mindlessly pawing the button that makes treats come out, while the games created with love and artistic integrity drown beneath waves of bottom-feeders like Hunt Down The Freeman, that tear chunks of rotten flesh from the corpses of Valve's children as Valve itself, once-habitual founders of new ages of narrative gaming, merely waves them on, barely glancing up from their tax paperwork?! You can't have it for six months, and then you have to pay another ten bucks for the special helmet with a bell-end on the front so everyone knows what a cockhead you are." At least consider it, so the next year, I'm not saying, "Hey guys, how about we all stop ticking the box that says, 'Sony have the exclusive ownership rights to our blood'?" "

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a very cherry-picked take on gaming circa 2020. I don't play a single one of those annualized franchises or live service games, and yet I have plenty of new things to look forward to. Final Fantasy VII isn't "fresh"; it's still, at its heart, a rehash of a game released decades ago, which by definition isn't anything truly new. Same with RE3. They may be good games, but they're hardly the banner children of newness you seem to want them to be.
I'm looking forward most this year to Cyberpunk 2077, The Last of Us 2, and Elden Ring. All completely new games, all without live service bullshit. There's also Watch Dogs: Legion, Vampire: Bloodlines 2, Baldur's Gate 3, Wasteland 3, and so on and so on.
snippet.textOriginal:
This is a very cherry-picked take on gaming circa 2020.  I don't play a single one of those annualized franchises or live service games, and yet I have plenty of new things to look forward to.  Final Fantasy VII isn't "fresh"; it's still, at its heart, a rehash of a game released decades ago, which by definition isn't anything truly new.  Same with RE3.  They may be good games, but they're hardly the banner children of newness you seem to want them to be.
I'm looking forward most this year to Cyberpunk 2077, The Last of Us 2, and Elden Ring.  All completely new games, all without live service bullshit.  There's also Watch Dogs: Legion, Vampire: Bloodlines 2, Baldur's Gate 3, Wasteland 3, and so on and so on.

Ori and the will of wisps that just came out and is fucking amazing.
Doom Eternal that is looking fucking amazing.
Cyberpunk 2077.
Resident Evil 3 but not because of nostalgia but because RE2 remake was fucking amazing and i trust RE3 to be just as good if not better.
I'm not really nostalgic for FF7 or old RE games because i never played them despite being the right age.
But i am excited for amazing games from the developers i trust. And that is something EA, ubisoft, activision or bethesda will never have - my trust.

snippet.textDisplay: People using game remakes as an inherent criticism of modern lack of creativity is bold faced horseshit and we all know it. There is precisely zero netcode from FFVII in it's remake. It's not like simply remastering a movie on Blu Ray. It's a brand new fucking game. These remakes are the same in only the broadest senses. They're starting from the same setting/scenario/character outlines and completely reimagining them.
snippet.textOriginal: People using game remakes as an inherent criticism of modern lack of creativity is bold faced horseshit and we all know it. There is precisely zero netcode from FFVII in it's remake. It's not like simply remastering a movie on Blu Ray. It's a brand new fucking game. These remakes are the same in only the broadest senses. They're starting from the same setting/scenario/character outlines and completely reimagining them.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is just so on the point. Really, I've spoken about this exact thing recently with both my partner and a friend, and different times.

What game am I most looking forward to this year? C&C Collection Remastered. Like, seriously. Why is that? Pretty much what you said here.
(Well I don't have a PS4 otherwise it might be FFVII Remake, but then also maybe not seems it's only the Midgar section of the game).

I find myself having absolutely zero interest in anything other than these sort of titles now. Everything new that is "Triple A" is just total garbage these days and full of deliberately handicapped gameplay to try to extort money from it's players. After playing both Anthem and Division 2 last year, I just have zero interest in anything else "Triple A" this year at all bar FFVII Remake (I'm sure Resi 3 Remake will be good too, but I'm yet to play the Resi 2 Remake though I own it, kinda go through phases with horror games and thats the only time I play them, so).

In otherwords, anything "Triple A" that I'm even slightly interested in, is always just a remake, because I guess they're less likely to fuck it up. And otherwise I expect these big companies to fully fuck up everything these days. SquareEnix it's only really being giving a pass here, because well, FFVII, and the fact that FFXV and Octopath Traveler are both semi-recent titles that were actually pretty good/really good respectively, so they still have my faith. For now.

What was the last actually new" 'fresh', game I really enjoyed? I think it was Greedfall. Which wasn't by one of those big wig Triple A developers, so...definitely a pattern.

snippet.textDisplay: Personally, I see Divinity II as a modern take on Baldur's Gate ('98) which itself was, while not the first (Ultima, for example), a digital attempt of Dungeons & Dragons ('74). Although not mentioned in the video, the other big game of the year, Cyberpunk 2077, seeing previews of the game make me reminiscent of the original Deus Ex ('00) (and to a lesser degree, System Shock ('94, '99)).
snippet.textOriginal: Personally, I see Divinity II as a modern take on Baldur's Gate ('98) which itself was, while not the first (Ultima, for example), a digital attempt of Dungeons & Dragons ('74). Although not mentioned in the video, the other big game of the year, Cyberpunk 2077, seeing previews of the game make me reminiscent of the original Deus Ex ('00) (and to a lesser degree, System Shock ('94, '99)).

snippet.textDisplay: Once upon a time, there would be dozens upon dozens of games a year I'd want to play. Creative and fresh titles made with love, passion and creative integrity. Now, there's maybe like 3 - 5 a year at best, and at least half of those are remakes. It's an abysmal state of affairs. These days, I just stay signed up to an MMO so when there's nothing new or fresh to play, I have something to do. On that note, "some FF bollocks" is that high on last years list for a reason, several in fact. An MMO manages to tell the best story in the Final Fantasy series full stop. Kind of embarrasing for Square Enix really, given how utterly poor recent Final Fantasy releases have been otherwise. I too am on board for the VII Remake after playing the demo though, my expectations were practically non-existent and I was pleasantly surprised that, at least from what we can tell, they haven't yet managed to fuck it up.
snippet.textOriginal: Once upon a time, there would be dozens upon dozens of games a year I'd want to play. Creative and fresh titles made with love, passion and creative integrity. Now, there's maybe like 3 - 5 a year at best, and at least half of those are remakes. It's an abysmal state of affairs. These days, I just stay signed up to an MMO so when there's nothing new or fresh to play, I have something to do. On that note, "some FF bollocks" is that high on last years list for a reason, several in fact. An MMO manages to tell the best story in the Final Fantasy series full stop. Kind of embarrasing for Square Enix really, given how utterly poor recent Final Fantasy releases have been otherwise. I too am on board for the VII Remake after playing the demo though, my expectations were practically non-existent and I was pleasantly surprised that, at least from what we can tell, they haven't yet managed to fuck it up.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nostalgia Sells. Look at Star Wars, Star Trek, Terminator, etc... Wait, no it doesn't. Saying that those games sell on nostalgia is a hypocrisy.
Dishonesty at it's finest. They are different product than the predecessors as they change gameplay and explorer new ideas.
They don't change the themes, retcon the old and try to show THEY ARE the same product, while don't give a damn about the source material and do demonize the already customers as toxic fans while trying push their marxists views to the world instead of keeping the product in it's own world. And you make $13,102 a month for being a bigot.

snippet.textDisplay: Nostalgia does indeed sell. FF7, RE, Return of Samus... It's the 90's.  We want to remember life from the 90's.  Back when there was hope. When no dream seemed impossible. When the future seemed exciting. When the biggest scandal we were worried about was whether the president lied about getting a blowjob. I can't tell all of you younger ones how great it was. How horrible the fucked up state of the world today seems in comparison. And I would give anything to go back.

When the future seemed exciting. When the biggest scandal we were worried about was whether the president lied about getting a blowjob. I can't tell all of you younger ones how great it was. How horrible the fucked up state of the world today seems in comparison. And I would give anything to go back.

Why didn't you mention that the gimmick with FF7R is: literally paying full price for 1/3 of the game!

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry, Jim, but you've got it backwards. The only thing that's a surer investment than a well-established franchise is a remake of a beloved entry in a well-established franchise. Have you noticed that they all have microtransactions, by the way? It may seem like you're sticking it to the man, but in reality you're praising the same system and principle that gave us lootboxes.
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry, Jim, but you've got it backwards. The only thing that's a surer investment than a well-established franchise is a remake of a beloved entry in a well-established franchise. Have you noticed that they all have microtransactions, by the way? It may seem like you're sticking it to the man, but in reality you're praising the same system and principle that gave us lootboxes.

snippet.textDisplay:
Totally agree with you, Jim!
Ditched all the new games now just to play original FF7 for the sake of rekindling the old sweet memories, can't wait for the remake. Even today it's still holding well with gameplay, I can't believe it -- so much things done in interesting way, like all those incorporated mini-games with SOLDIER chores, bike chasing (hello to the Astral Chain, lol) and other sections.


With optional content they went overboard in some ways. I mean, come on, they even have fucking tower defense! Imagine how all that things got paywalled with nowadays greedy AAA companies practicies...


I am not even nearly excited for all the new upcoming stuff as I now with FF7R and RE3R.
Really hope they do well in sales and reception. Gonna buy physical on launch and digital copies after, so much rooting for the good ol' games without bloated services shit.
snippet.textOriginal:
Totally agree with you, Jim!
Ditched all the new games now just to play original FF7 for the sake of rekindling the old sweet memories, can't wait for the remake. Even today it's still holding well with gameplay, I can't believe it -- so much things done in interesting way, like all those incorporated mini-games with SOLDIER chores, bike chasing (hello to the Astral Chain, lol) and other sections.


With optional content they went overboard in some ways. I mean, come on, they even have fucking tower defense! Imagine how all that things got paywalled with nowadays greedy AAA companies practicies...


I am not even nearly excited for all the new upcoming stuff as I now with FF7R and RE3R.
Really hope they do well in sales and reception. Gonna buy physical on launch and digital copies after, so much rooting for the good ol' games without bloated services shit.

snippet.textDisplay:
Kinda feel bad about the next generation when '8k' games although not that big a jump in terms of cost to produce since they won't be '8k native', if it's even a focus on upscaling or just lies, but we'll see. We'll see if there's still compromises to produce more sustainable (through DLC) epic titles like Horizon Zero Dawn.

Also it's entitlement. How do studios battle the entitlement of players that will rip on anything that isn't perfect, looks at No Man's Sky? And still take risks to make instant classics like HZD, cyberpunk (fingers crossed), and Witcher 3.. that have action and story.
snippet.textOriginal:
Kinda feel bad about the next generation when '8k' games although not that big a jump in terms of cost to produce since they won't be '8k native', if it's even a focus on upscaling or just lies, but we'll see. We'll see if there's still compromises to produce more sustainable (through DLC) epic titles like Horizon Zero Dawn.

Also it's entitlement. How do studios battle the entitlement of players that will rip on anything that isn't perfect, looks at No Man's Sky? And still take risks to make instant classics like HZD, cyberpunk (fingers crossed), and Witcher 3.. that have action and story.

snippet.textDisplay: The interesting thing is with how popular these remakes are and are going to be lol it could in itself turn into a bandwagon with companies remaking any popular game in their back catalogue it's kind of genius from a marketing point because you already have a devoted fan base for the game you have yet to release it's almost impossible to fuck it up and if it trends we could see some really cool shit

snippet.textDisplay: I've been working on a game for a while and looking at the gaming world makes me want to quit and get a real job. Wolcen dumbass of darkness or whatever has 10k people playing it. There's a game on steam where you literally just sit there waiting for 400 days that has 95% positive out of 400 reviews. Why should I spend any of my time making things when the world is full of idiots?
